message.content:
cs.IT, cs.CC, cs.CR, cs.SI, cs.MM 

The paper is focused on network information theory (NIT) problems, which typically fall under the category of information theory (cs.IT). The paper also covers a variety of settings including channel coding, joint source-channel coding, feedback, and relaying, which are all subfields of information theory. Therefore, cs.IT is the most likely sub-category. 

The paper also discusses coordination and secrecy problems, which are related to cryptography and security (cs.CR). 

The use of random binning arguments and pmf approximation arguments suggests that the paper may also be relevant to coding theory (cs.CC) and statistical inference (cs.SI). 

Finally, the paper mentions lossy source coding, which is related to multimedia (cs.MM). 

Overall, the most likely sub-categories are cs.IT, cs.CC, cs.CR, cs.SI, and cs.MM, in that order.
